channel.title: Excuse me
channel.description:
Pretty sure the American cars are #1. Last time I checked, fastest, best handling PRODUCTION CAR (this means it's made in a factory with enough cars being made to be considered production) is the Corvette ZR1. Discuss.
Plus my car will poop on any europeans car, don't care if it's only in a strait line or if I spend more money on fuel when my car idles then when you are at 7,000 RPM.

item.title: Excuse me
item.dc:creator: @Thebeanie TheBeanie
item.description:
@Thebeanie wrote:

[quote=“zoltanman, post:28, topic:326443”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=422854.msg3111613#msg3111613 date=1264590859]

Probably all purpose built German and Italian cars too, the corvette is the first car to even get close to European handling, but not close enough.

Then explain why the Dodge Viper ACR still holds the record for the fastest production car on the European Nürburgring? Which everyone will agree is about as far away from a straight line as you can get.

It’s not debatable that we have the fastest cars in a straight line, but records seem to point to the fact that at least 2 of our vehicles are fastest or near-fastest on road tracks as well. Certainly they are the fastest cars on any type of track for the money.

^^Without a doubt in terms of cost.

It was fastest round the Nürburgring for a production car indeed, a Lotus or Atom couldn’t touch it on raw speed I agree. Obviously power outweighs handling in a race. Despite this if you look at actual purpose built racers the European cars dominate the leaderboards. The fact is, we do manage to get more bhp out of smaller engines, but in doing so we increase costs hence why our best cars are at the top of the boards but are too expensive to be mass produced.

America are now in F1 and for me this is going to be the real competition, although when I mentioned this in another thread the Americans seemed uninterested. Kind of stupid really, F1 is at the forefront of racing, and no doubt you’ll have more money to throw at it than us. I mean, even BMW withdrew from F1 this year, so economic crisis has left the sport open to the taking of any team willing to put the effort in.

EDIT: Actually the Gumpert Apollo is a production car and thats over 10 seconds faster than the Dodge. The Radical is actually the fastest but it’s widely debated that its not a production car, and in my opinion it isn’t.

There’s plenty of sources stating this: http://www.autoblog.com/2009/08/18/gumpert-apollo-sport-sets-new-production-car-lap-record-at-nur/

Wikipedia’s lap time board also confirms this. 700bhp out of 4.2l engine is pretty intense and so is the price tag.

[/quote]

Throwing forced induction on a small engine to get big numbers is not an achievement. The ZR1 is the only car up on the leaderboard that can be driven every day, besides the GTR. The Apollo is just a race car for the streets, and cannot be driven every day like a GTR or ZR1 can.

Lmfao, american cars aren’t “The best handling”, they can go in a straight line, they cannot corner for shit.

Shows how much ignorance you have, explain why the ZR1 has faster lap times on a track than a LP670-4 SV?

I was talking about the Pontiac you linked to not being stock, at least it didn’t look like it

But it’s not just the interiors, it’s the body as well. I can’t remember if it was a corvette I saw or what, but when you leaned on the back or sides, the panels were such a thin plastic they just bent inwards. I saw this first on Top Gear, then actually got to try it myself a few weeks later.

I think the true test of American performance will be if they manage F1…
http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2009/2/8955.html

They’re cheap performance bargains, good interior and luxury is not going to be offered. If you want to see a car that doesn’t have a budget, then look up the Pratt&Miller C6RS.[/quote]

I shall ask my mate on the gumpert as he has a gumpert apollo sport (it was HIS car that was on top gear :P) and he co-owned Gumpert-UK In burnley.

Read full topic

item.title: Excuse me
item.dc:creator: @zoltanman zoltanman
item.description:
@zoltanman wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:20, topic:326443”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=422854.msg3111607#msg3111607 date=1264589875]

Probably all purpose built German and Italian cars too, the corvette is the first car to even get close to European handling, but not close enough.

Then explain why the Dodge Viper ACR still holds the record for the fastest production car on the European Nürburgring? Which everyone will agree is about as far away from a straight line as you can get.

It’s not debatable that we have the fastest cars in a straight line, but records seem to point to the fact that at least 2 of our vehicles are fastest or near-fastest on road tracks as well. Certainly they are the fastest cars on any type of track for the money.
[/quote]
^^Without a doubt in terms of cost.

It was fastest round the Nürburgring for a production car indeed, a Lotus or Atom couldn’t touch it on raw speed I agree. Obviously power outweighs handling in a race. Despite this if you look at actual purpose built racers the European cars dominate the leaderboards. The fact is, we do manage to get more bhp out of smaller engines, but in doing so we increase costs hence why our best cars are at the top of the boards but are too expensive to be mass produced.

America are now in F1 and for me this is going to be the real competition, although when I mentioned this in another thread the Americans seemed uninterested. Kind of stupid really, F1 is at the forefront of racing, and no doubt you’ll have more money to throw at it than us. I mean, even BMW withdrew from F1 this year, so economic crisis has left the sport open to the taking of any team willing to put the effort in.

EDIT: Actually the Gumpert Apollo is a production car and thats over 10 seconds faster than the Dodge. The Radical is actually the fastest but it’s widely debated that its not a production car, and in my opinion it isn’t.

There’s plenty of sources stating this: http://www.autoblog.com/2009/08/18/gumpert-apollo-sport-sets-new-production-car-lap-record-at-nur/

Wikipedia’s lap time board also confirms this. 700bhp out of 4.2l engine is pretty intense and so is the price tag.[/quote]

Throwing forced induction on a small engine to get big numbers is not an achievement. The ZR1 is the only car up on the leaderboard that can be driven every day, besides the GTR. The Apollo is just a race car for the streets, and cannot be driven every day like a GTR or ZR1 can.

The_Owner:

Lmfao, american cars aren’t “The best handling”, they can go in a straight line, they cannot corner for shit.

Shows how much ignorance you have, explain why the ZR1 has faster lap times on a track than a LP670-4 SV?

[quote=“Greeny, post:7, topic:326443”]I was talking about the Pontiac you linked to not being stock, at least it didn’t look like it

But it’s not just the interiors, it’s the body as well. I can’t remember if it was a corvette I saw or what, but when you leaned on the back or sides, the panels were such a thin plastic they just bent inwards. I saw this first on Top Gear, then actually got to try it myself a few weeks later.

I think the true test of American performance will be if they manage F1…

Formula 1® - The Official F1® Website

Latest

Latest

They’re cheap performance bargains, good interior and luxury is not going to be offered. If you want to see a car that doesn’t have a budget, then look up the Pratt&Miller C6RS.

Read full topic

item.title: Excuse me
item.dc:creator: @zraffz zraffz
item.description:
@zraffz wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:26, topic:326443”]The Atom is street legal in the UK and it is now being manufactured in the US because of its popularity (some company bought the rights I think) where it is street legal (in some states, not all). In addition to that there is in fact a couple of years waiting list for it here in the UK, so I’d argue its a production vehicle. Production vehicle though is indeed a loose term, hence why the production vehicle Nürburgring lap is “unofficial” in every sense of the word.

I can’t crunch the technical stuff like you can because I’m no expert on the subject, so I literally just have to take your word on it. I wouldn’t claim to know more than you, I can only claim to know what I read while browsing through articles and personal experience.

In response to your comments of the Gumpert, I don’t want to call you ignorant (you’re clearly not) but that car is pretty phenomenal in every aspect. The reason its so ugly is because the car was designed to grip whilst being aerodynamic and if it’s as simple as you put it surely others would have done it?[/quote]
Well I know what I read but the only knowledge I can back up is my hands on experience of motors, the only suspension I know how to set up is that of a car built to go in a strait line. Other then that I just assume what I read is true.

Their is no reason to argue anything (not saying that you are), we can agree to disagree.

Read full topic

item.title: Excuse me
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

The Atom is street legal in the UK and it is now being manufactured in the US because of its popularity (some company bought the rights I think) where it is street legal (in some states, not all). In addition to that there is in fact a couple of years waiting list for it here in the UK, so I’d argue its a production vehicle. Production vehicle though is indeed a loose term, hence why the production vehicle Nürburgring lap is “unofficial” in every sense of the word.

I can’t crunch the technical stuff like you can because I’m no expert on the subject, so I literally just have to take your word on it. I wouldn’t claim to know more than you, I can only claim to know what I read while browsing through articles and personal experience.

In response to your comments of the Gumpert, I don’t want to call you ignorant (you’re clearly not) but that car is pretty phenomenal in every aspect. The reason its so ugly is because the car was designed to grip whilst being aerodynamic and if it’s as simple as you put it surely others would have done it?

Read full topic

item.title: Excuse me
item.dc:creator: @zraffz zraffz
item.description:
@zraffz wrote:

Greeny:

Wikipedia’s lap time board also confirms this. 700bhp out of 4.2l engine is pretty intense and so is the price tag.

Not impressed by that. Any company can take a car with a severely over-worked set of heads and some form of forced induction to achieve power like that.

I have a few problems with the Ariel Atom, first off they don’t make enough to classify as a real production vehicle and second that thing in no way resembles a car. It’s open wheel wells and has a tube chassis, their is almost no place atleast in America where that thing is street legal.
Ariel Atom
Production <100 per year

I am not sure what a mass production vehicle is classified by anymore, in the 60’s it used to be 500 of a vehicle had to be made for it to be a production vehicle. Now with the large increase in cars and drivers I imagine a real production car must be way more then that number.

And I couldn’t find a Lotus that actually outhandled the Corvette at 1.06G on the skidpad. And if you really want to get technical I know nothing will beat the ACR at 1.5G.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

He pretty much invented the assembly line, and mass production of cars. The Ford Model T however wasn’t the first petrol driven vehicle (At least I think the Model T was his first car). My flatmate does Engineering and he did a presentation on this stuff so I know quite a bit but it’s second hand information.

item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:326443”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=422854.msg3111537#msg3111537 date=1264583605]
Probably all purpose built German and Italian cars too, the corvette is the first car to even get close to European handling, but not close enough.
[/quote]

Then explain why the Dodge Viper ACR still holds the record for the fastest production car on the European Nürburgring? Which everyone will agree is about as far away from a straight line as you can get.

It’s not debatable that we have the fastest cars in a straight line, but records seem to point to the fact that at least 2 of our vehicles are fastest or near-fastest on road tracks as well. Certainly they are the fastest cars on any type of track for the money.[/quote]
^^Without a doubt in terms of cost.

It was fastest round the Nürburgring for a production car indeed, a Lotus or Atom couldn’t touch it on raw speed I agree. Obviously power outweighs handling in a race. Despite this if you look at actual purpose built racers the European cars dominate the leaderboards. The fact is, we do manage to get more bhp out of smaller engines, but in doing so we increase costs hence why our best cars are at the top of the boards but are too expensive to be mass produced.

America are now in F1 and for me this is going to be the real competition, although when I mentioned this in another thread the Americans seemed uninterested. Kind of stupid really, F1 is at the forefront of racing, and no doubt you’ll have more money to throw at it than us. I mean, even BMW withdrew from F1 this year, so economic crisis has left the sport open to the taking of any team willing to put the effort in.

EDIT: Actually the Gumpert Apollo is a production car and thats over 10 seconds faster than the Dodge. The Radical is actually the fastest but it’s widely debated that its not a production car, and in my opinion it isn’t.

There’s plenty of sources stating this: http://www.autoblog.com/2009/08/18/gumpert-apollo-sport-sets-new-production-car-lap-record-at-nur/

Wikipedia’s lap time board also confirms this. 700bhp out of 4.2l engine is pretty intense and so is the price tag.

item.title: Excuse me
item.dc:creator: @zraffz zraffz
item.description:
@zraffz wrote:

Nobody cares what the inside of their car looks like. Us Americans don’t buy domestic cars caring that we have a plastic dashboard or a car made out of fiberglass or that our interior looks like it was designed by a 6th grader. The goal of a true sports car is perfomance, nothing else really matters.
Why don’t you watch videos of the modern super cars being compared to the Corvette and Viper? Perfomance wise, they are very close but the price tag is usually $50,000+ more for the european super car. I’d rather save the $50,000 and have a crap interior.

oh and my Chevy is stock

Read full topic
